items.title: Dal contrasto al jamming satellitare alle nuove minacce spaziali: la sfida europea delle comunicazioni laser
items.description: Lo spazio non è più soltanto una frontiera tecnologica o commerciale. Negli ultimi mesi diversi funzionari e leader europei hanno sottolineato che il
items.body:
By:  Simone Cantarini  |  EURACTIV Italia    28 Novembre 2025|12:17             
            
                
        
    [freepik/Vecstock]            
        
     
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

Lo spazio non è più soltanto una frontiera tecnologica o commerciale. Negli ultimi mesi diversi funzionari e leader europei hanno sottolineato che il “dominio spaziale” sta diventando un’arena strategica che incide direttamente sulla sicurezza globale e sull’economia. Laurynas Mačiulis, CEO e co-fondatore della lituana Astrolight, avverte che i sistemi satellitari sono ormai la nuova linea del fronte nella guerra ibrida e che l’Europa non si sta muovendo abbastanza in fretta per proteggerli.
In un’intervista rilasciata a Euractiv Italia, Mačiulis avverte che l’aumento delle attività di jamming russe nel Baltico e nell’Europa orientale ha già messo in luce criticità profonde nell’infrastruttura spaziale europea. “Persino persone che lavorano in alcune aree vicino all’Ucraina, e in Ucraina stessa vicino ai Paesi baltici, possono riscontrare problemi con il GPS che viene falsificato o disturbato”, spiega. “Questo è uno strumento di guerra ibrida. Serve a testare la nostra resilienza, a verificare quanto siamo vulnerabili”, sottolinea Mačiulis rilanciando un allarme espresso più volte in questi mesi anche dal commissario europeo alla Difesa e allo Spazio ed ex premier lituano, Andrius Kubilius.
Secondo il Ceo di Astrolight, però, l’escalation non si limita ai segnali visibili. Il vero pericolo risiede in ciò che gli avversari stanno preparando: disattivare completamente i satelliti. “Dato che dipendiamo sempre di più dai satelliti per navigazione, comunicazioni, geo-intelligence… è evidente che tutte le grandi potenze del mondo stanno cercando il modo per spegnere questo segmento, per eliminarlo completamente in caso di conflitto”, afferma. Gran parte di queste attività, sottolinea, avviene “meno pubblicamente”, anche se i vertici militari stanno lanciando allarmi sempre più insistenti.
La guerra in Ucraina è stata un punto di svolta. Quando le reti di comunicazione terrestri sono state danneggiate, Kyiv è passata rapidamente a Starlink, dimostrando quanto la dimensione spaziale fosse diventata vitale. “Quando l’Ucraina è passata a Starlink in molte regioni, ci siamo resi conto di quanto lo spazio potesse essere importante”, ricorda Mačiulis. “Naturalmente, [gli avversari] stanno preparando mezzi e tecnologie per spegnere o eliminare anche questo segmento. Dobbiamo essere vigili”, precisa.

Lo spazio è un nuovo campo di battaglia per la Russia e l’Europa deve difendersi, avverte il commissario UE Kubilius
La Russia sta utilizzando lo spazio come campo di battaglia nel suo confronto con l’Ucraina e l’Occidente. A lanciare l’allarme è il commissario europeo per la Difesa e lo Spazio, intervenuto venerdì 12 settembre agli Stati generali di Difesa, Spazio …

La vulnerabilità delle comunicazioni tramite radiofrequenze
I tradizionali collegamenti satellitari a radiofrequenza (RF) sono diventati un bersaglio facile in ambienti contestati. Mačiulis ne descrive il meccanismo con estrema semplicità: “I sistemi a radiofrequenza emettono segnali che diffondono la loro energia su un’area molto ampia. I ricevitori radio sono sensibili ai segnali provenienti da più direzioni. È piuttosto facile intercettarli, perché puoi tracciarli, rilevarli, e se sai dov’è l’oggetto puoi dirigere un segnale interferente che anneghi quello utile nel rumore dell’avversario”.
Starlink e altre costellazioni in orbita bassa sono particolarmente esposte perché ogni satellite illumina aree vaste con più fasci. E poiché le orbite sono ovviamente visibili a tutti, è “impossibile nascondere il satellite, perché vola nello spazio e se ne conoscono le coordinate”, aggiunge.
“Puoi puntare l’antenna verso il satellite ed emettere un segnale interferente molto potente… e il ricevitore non sarà in grado di distinguere il segnale utile da quello interferente”, spiega il CEO di Astrolight.
Mačiulis mette in guardia anche su uno scenario che non è più ipotetico: jammer montati direttamente su satelliti in orbita. “Se riesci a portare un tuo satellite con jammer a bordo e avvicinarlo al satellite che vuoi disturbare, diventa ancora più facile… potresti condurre una forma di guerra ibrida causando ingenti danni senza esporti”.

L'ESA approva un budget record da oltre 22 miliardi di euro. Aschbacher: "risultato storico"
La European Space Agency riceverà nei prossimi tre anni un finanziamento di 22,07 miliardi di euro, un balzo senza precedenti rispetto ai 16,9 miliardi approvati per il triennio 2023-2025 che vede la ministeriale che si è conclusa il 27 novembre …

Le comunicazioni laser sono praticamente impossibili da disturbare
Fondata nel 2019, Astrolight è tra le poche aziende europee che sviluppano terminali avanzati per comunicazioni laser, una tecnologia che riduce drasticamente il rischio di intercettazione o jamming.
La ragione è fisica. “Questa tecnologia usa laser a infrarossi invece delle onde radio. Il fascio laser è molto stretto — dell’ordine di millesimi di grado”, spiega Mačiulis. “Se proietti un laser da 1.000 chilometri di distanza, il punto a terra ha un diametro di circa 100 metri”.
Mantenere un fascio così preciso allineato tra due satelliti che si muovono a 8 km/s è estremamente complesso — “è il nostro know-how e in realtà il nostro risultato più grande”, afferma. Una volta stabilito il collegamento ottico, però, i vantaggi in termini di sicurezza sono decisivi: “Solo l’oggetto verso il quale punti il laser può ricevere l’informazione, e nessun altro può intercettare o disturbare il segnale… è praticamente impossibile posizionare un oggetto in grado di manovrare alla velocità necessaria per restare nella linea di vista”.
Come indicato Mačiulis le comunicazioni laser non sono più sperimentali. Gli alleati della NATO, la Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture degli Stati Uniti, Starlink e presto la costellazione europea IRIS² fanno affidamento su collegamenti ottici inter-satellitari. Astrolight ha testato le sue tecnologie nelle esercitazioni NATO REPMUS con la Marina lituana, contrastando l’idea che i laser siano inaffidabili in presenza di nuvole o condizioni meteo avverse.
“Molti, sia militari che civili, pensano ancora che non saranno affidabili a causa delle nuvole e di altri problemi”, dice. “Dobbiamo solo dimostrare che si sbagliano… una volta che i sistemi saranno operativi, anche altri inizieranno a usarli. Serve un effetto valanga iniziale”.

Spazio, nuova frontiera della sicurezza: l’UE cerca unità contro Russia e Cina
Lo spazio non è più soltanto un orizzonte tecnologico o commerciale, ma sta diventando sempre di più un terreno di competizione strategica che incide sulla sicurezza e sull’economia globale. Questi temi sono stati al centro della Training School on Space …

Perché l’Artico conterà per la resilienza europea
Nel 2026, Astrolight installerà una stazione di terra artica in Groenlandia — una mossa che Mačiulis considera strategicamente essenziale per la resilienza europea a lungo termine.
“Nell’Artico c’è una forte carenza di infrastrutture di comunicazione, ma le attività stanno aumentando — civili e militari”, afferma. Un migliore accesso è necessario anche per operazioni di ricerca e soccorso, attività scientifiche e servizi digitali di base.
Ma la vera importanza strategica è legata ai satelliti di intelligence. “Quasi tutti i satelliti di geo-intelligence usati dai Paesi alleati volano in orbite polari… quando passano sul circolo polare, è il momento migliore per scaricare i dati”. Le Isole Svalbard sono già un hub importante, ma manca ridondanza. “Pensiamo che la Groenlandia sia una posizione strategica eccellente… non solo per il radio, ma anche per l’ottico, che offrirebbe maggiore capacità e più sicurezza contro eventuali jamming”.
In Europa ci sono ancora frammentazione e burocrazia
Per Mačiulis, il principale ostacolo europeo non è tecnologico o industriale, ma politico. Finanziamenti frammentati e ambizioni nazionali sovrapposte rallentano il continente.
“I diversi Paesi europei vogliono avere indipendenza… soprattutto i più grandi vogliono sviluppare le proprie soluzioni”, spiega. “Probabilmente si spendono troppi soldi in programmi di R&S, mentre sarebbe meglio convogliarli verso capitali privati capaci di prendere decisioni commercialmente informate su chi sia più forte e più adatto a risolvere il problema”.
Il modello indicato da Mačiulis è semplice: definire chiaramente il problema, sostenere la soluzione più solida e permettere alle aziende di consolidarsi naturalmente. Cita l’esempio di Airbus, “quando l’Europa creò un’azienda comune e sviluppò il proprio aereo da trasporto”.
“Bisogna cooperare e sfruttare i punti di forza dei diversi Paesi per creare un prodotto altamente competitivo”.

items.title: Il piano di Várhelyi per una tassa alimentare nell’UE suscita reazioni negative all’interno della Commissione europea
items.description: L’idea di imporre una tassa UE sugli alimenti e le bevande altamente trasformati con un elevato contenuto di grassi, zuccheri e sale sta incontr
items.body:
By:  Angelo di Mambro  |  EURACTIV  | translated by  Alessia Peretti    28 Novembre 2025|11:30  (aggiornato:  28 Novembre 2025|12:30 )            
            
                
        
    Il commissario europeo per la Salute e il Benessere degli animali Olivér Várhelyi [Lukasz Kobus - Source EC - Audiovisual Service - European Union, 2019]            
        
     
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

L’idea di imporre una tassa UE sugli alimenti e le bevande altamente trasformati con un elevato contenuto di grassi, zuccheri e sale sta incontrando una forte opposizione all’interno della Commissione europea, secondo i documenti visionati da Euractiv.
La proposta di una tassa alimentare è inclusa nella bozza del piano sanitario cardiovascolare dell’UE, attualmente in discussione all’interno dell’esecutivo dell’Unione, e dovrebbe essere presentata il 16 dicembre.
La prima versione della strategia, elaborata dal commissario alla Salute Olivér Várhelyi e ottenuta da Euractiv, suggerisce di introdurre entro il 2026 una tassa a livello UE sugli alimenti altamente trasformati, ricchi di grassi, zuccheri e sale, nonché sugli alcopop. L’obiettivo è ridurre il rischio di malattie cardiovascolari.
Secondo i documenti visionati da Euractiv, almeno quattro dipartimenti della Commissione hanno espresso un parere negativo in merito.
La Direzione generale dell’Agricoltura ha sollevato “punti di grave preoccupazione” e ha ricordato che, nella sua “Visione per il futuro dell’agricoltura e dell’alimentazione”, la Commissione si era impegnata a condurre uno studio sull’impatto degli alimenti ultra-trasformati prima di intraprendere qualsiasi ulteriore azione.

L'UE vuole tassare il cibo non sano e gli alcopop nell'ambito della bozza del piano per la salute del cuore
Secondo una prima bozza del Piano per la salute cardiovascolare ottenuta da Euractiv.com, la Commissione europea vorrebbe imporre imposte a livello europeo sugli alimenti ultra-processati e sugli alcopop (bevande alcoliche pronte da bere, solitamente con una bassa gradazione alcolica) entro …

“La discussione [sulla tassazione dei prodotti alimentari] è ancora in corso… ma ritengo che l’accessibilità economica dei prodotti alimentari per i consumatori debba essere il nostro principio guida”, ha dichiarato il commissario europeo all’Agricoltura Christophe Hansen a margine del Consiglio Agricoltura del 17 novembre. Ha anche accennato ad alternative alle nuove tasse, come l’esenzione dall’IVA per i prodotti biologici.
Il dipartimento GROW, responsabile del mercato unico e dell’industria, ha inoltre sottolineato la necessità di ulteriori ricerche e di un miglioramento dell’“accuratezza scientifica” del piano.
Sono necessarie ulteriori ricerche “sulla misura in cui la trasformazione degli alimenti stessi ha un impatto negativo sulla salute”. Il contributo della DG GROW ha anche ricordato che i paesi dell’UE potrebbero “invocare la sussidiarietà” per attuare regimi fiscali nazionali.
Anche il parere della DG Bilancio è negativo, in quanto una proposta di nuova imposta nel 2026 “potrebbe compromettere seriamente” i difficili negoziati in corso sul bilancio a lungo termine dell’UE, che dovrebbe entrare in vigore nel 2028.
Il servizio bilancio, così come la DG Fiscalità, hanno criticato la mancanza di chiarezza sul fatto che l’imposta sarebbe considerata una “nuova risorsa propria”, con quest’ultima che ha espresso “forti riserve” sul piano.

Le “industrie del vizio” dell’Unione europea si fanno la guerra sulle tasse
A porte chiuse, i vertici delle industrie europee dei cosiddetti prodotti “peccaminosi” – alcol, tabacco, cibo spazzatura e bevande zuccherate – sono impegnati in una feroce battaglia su chi debba essere il primo a subire un aumento delle imposte europee.
In …

Come descritto nella bozza del piano cardiovascolare, sostengono, l’imposta sarebbe soggetta a una legislazione speciale e richiederebbe l’unanimità dei paesi dell’UE per essere approvata.
Parlando al Collegio dei Commissari lo scorso luglio, Wopke Hoekstra, commissario europeo responsabile tra l’altro della fiscalità, ha affermato che le tasse sui prodotti di consumo ad alto contenuto di sale o zucchero potrebbero essere un’opzione, ma solo per il futuro bilancio a lungo termine, dopo il 2034.

items.title: From countering satellite jamming to the threat in Space: Astrolight and Europe’s challenge of secure laser communications
items.description: Space is no longer just a technological or commercial frontier. As European officials and leader stated during these months it is increasingly becomin
items.body:
By:  Simone Cantarini  |  EURACTIV Italia    28 Novembre 2025|11:26             
            
                
        
    Foto illustrativa Satellite Sentinel-5P. [ESA - European Space Agency]            
        
     
        
            
                Stampa Email Facebook X LinkedIn WhatsApp Telegram

Space is no longer just a technological or commercial frontier. As European officials and leader stated during these months it is increasingly becoming a strategic arena that directly shapes global security and the economy. Laurynas Mačiulis, CEO and co-founder of the Lithuanian company Astrolight, has a clear message about this point: satellite systems are becoming the new front line of hybrid warfare, and Europe is not moving fast enough to protect them.
Speaking to Euractiv Italy, Mačiulis warns that the rise in Russian jamming across the Baltic and Eastern Europe has already exposed critical weaknesses in Europe’s space-based infrastructure. “Even people working in some areas near Ukraine, and in Ukraine also near the Baltics, they can experience issues with GPS being spoofed or jammed,” he says. “This is a kind of instrument for hybrid warfare. It’s an instrument to check our resilience, to check how vulnerable we are”.
According to him, the escalation is not limited to visible disruptions. The real danger lies in what adversaries are preparing for: disabling satellites altogether. “Given how more and more dependent we are becoming on satellites in terms of navigation, communication, geo-intelligence… it’s obvious that all the major powers in the world are looking at how to switch off the segment, how to essentially eliminate this segment in case of conflict,” he explains. Much of this, he stresses, happens “less publicly”, even if military officials are increasingly sounding the alarm.
The war in Ukraine has been a turning point. When terrestrial communication networks were damaged, Kyiv switched quickly to Starlink, which demonstrated how vital the space layer had become. “Once Ukraine switched to Starlink in many regions we realised how important space could be”, Mačiulis says. “Of course, [adversaries] are preparing the means and technologies to also switch off or eliminate this segment. So we have to be vigilant”.
The vulnerability of RF communications
Traditional radio-frequency (RF) satellite links have become an easy target in contested environments. Mačiulis lays out the mechanism with stark simplicity: “Radio-frequency systems emit signals that essentially spread their energy over a wide area. Radio receivers are sensitive to signals arriving from different directions. It’s quite easy to intercept those signals because you can track them, detect them, and if you know where the object is, you can direct an interfering signal that makes the useful signal drown in the interfering noise of the enemy”.
Starlink and other low-Earth-orbit constellations are particularly exposed because each satellite illuminates large territories with multiple beams. And since orbits are publicly known, “it’s impossible to conceal the satellite because it’s flying in space, you know its coordinates”, he says.
“You can basically point the antenna at the satellite and emit a very strong interfering signal… and the receiver will not be able to differentiate between the positive signal and the interfering signal”.
Mačiulis also warns about a scenario that is no longer hypothetical: jammers mounted directly on orbiting satellites. “If you can get your satellite with jammers on board and fly closer to the satellite you want to jam, then it becomes even easier… you could wage some kind of hybrid warfare where you could cause a lot of damage without exposing yourself”, he says.
Laser communications are practically almost impossible to jam
Astrolight is among the few European companies developing advanced laser communication terminals — a technology that drastically reduces the risk of interception or jamming.
The reason is physical. “This technology uses infrared lasers instead of radio waves. The laser beam we use is very narrow — in the order of thousandths of a degree”, Mačiulis explains. “If you shine the laser from 1,000 kilometres, you would have a beam spot of around 100 metres on the ground only from such a huge distance”.
Keeping such a sharp beam locked between two satellites moving at 8 km/s is extremely complex — “our know-how and actually our biggest achievement”, he says. But once the optical link is established, the security benefits are decisive: “Only the object where you point the laser can receive this information and nobody else outside can either intercept the signal or jam the signal… it’s practically almost impossible to put an object that could manoeuvre at the speed necessary to keep within this line of sight”.
Laser communications are no longer experimental. NATO allies, the United States’ Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture, Starlink and soon the EU’s IRIS² constellation all rely on optical inter-satellite links. Astrolight itself has tested its technologies during NATO’s REPMUS exercises with the Lithuanian Navy, countering the perception that lasers are unreliable in cloudy or adverse weather.
“Many military and non-military people still think this is not going to be reliable because of the clouds and other issues,” he says. “So we just need to prove they are wrong… once systems are deployed operationally, then other players will start using it as well. There needs to be an initial snowball effect”.
Why the Arctic will matter for Europe’s resilience
In 2026, Astrolight will deploy an Arctic ground station in Greenland — a move Mačiulis believes is strategically essential for Europe’s long-term resilience.
“In the Arctic there is quite a lack of communications infrastructure, but the activity is increasing — both civilian and military”, he says. Better connectivity is needed also for search and rescue, research activities and basic digital services.
But the real strategic importance is tied to intelligence satellites. “Basically, almost all geo-intelligence satellites used by allied countries are flying in polar orbits… once they are around the polar circle, then it’s the best time to get the data down”. Svalbard is already a major hub, but redundancy is missing. “We think Greenland is a very good strategic location… not only radio, but also optical, which would provide higher throughput and also higher security and resilience against potential jamming”.
In Europe there is still fragmentation and bureaucracy
For Mačiulis, Europe’s biggest obstacle is neither technological nor industrial — it’s political. Fragmented funding and overlapping national ambitions slow Europe down.
“Different European countries want to have independence… especially larger European countries want to develop their own things”, he explains. “There is probably too much money spent on a lot of R&D programmes, whereas it would be better to divert it to pro-private capital making commercially informed decisions about who are the strongest, the best fit to solve the problem”.
His preferred model is straightforward: define the problem clearly, support the most capable solution, and allow companies to consolidate naturally. “Take the example of Airbus, when Europe created a joint company and created its own transport aircraft”, he says. “You need to cooperate and use the strengths of different countries to create a very competitive product”, he explains.

Alimentazione
                             
                                                
                                        Spendevo il mio stipendio al bar, poi ci ha pensato Lidl: con questo piccolo elettrodomestico colazioni da re

Clarissa Missarelli

Novembre 28, 2025

Offerte imperdibili da Lidl - Greenstyle.it

Il nuovo montalatte Silvercrest di Lidl offre schiuma cremosa e quattro programmi per ogni esigenza, unendo praticità, design compatto e prezzo accessibile.

Per tutti gli appassionati di caffè che desiderano portare a casa l’esperienza di un cappuccino artigianale senza dover andare al bar, arriva una soluzione pratica e conveniente firmata Lidl. Il nuovo montalatte Silvercrest, da oggi disponibile, promette di fare la differenza nella routine mattutina grazie a funzionalità avanzate e un prezzo molto competitivo.
Da Lidl un montalatte professionale a portata di mano
Il montalatte elettrico Silvercrest si presenta come un elettrodomestico semplice da utilizzare ma estremamente versatile, perfetto per chi vuole preparare una schiuma di latte densa e cremosa con pochi passaggi. Proposto a soli 17,99 euro, il dispositivo si colloca come un prodotto di grande interesse per chi desidera un accessorio di qualità senza investire cifre elevate.
Tra le caratteristiche tecniche spicca la potenza di 500 watt, che consente un riscaldamento rapido e una montatura del latte efficiente, garantendo risultati simili a quelli di un barista. Il design compatto ne facilita l’inserimento in ogni cucina, anche in spazi ridotti, mentre un solo tasto permette di selezionare quattro programmi diversi in modo intuitivo.
Non perdere il montalatte Lidl – Greenstyle.it
Il punto di forza del montalatte Silvercrest è la sua adattabilità alle diverse preferenze di gusto e consistenza. Gli utenti possono scegliere tra:

schiuma leggera e compatta, ideale per un cappuccino dal sapore tradizionale e deciso;
schiuma calda e cremosa, perfetta per chi ama una texture più morbida e avvolgente;
riscaldamento del latte senza schiuma, adatto a chi preferisce un latte caldo semplice o una colazione meno elaborata;
schiuma fredda, pensata per preparare bevande estive come frappè e caffè freddo.

Queste modalità consentono di personalizzare la preparazione in base al momento della giornata o alle preferenze personali, rendendo l’elettrodomestico adatto a tutta la famiglia e a ogni stagione.
Il contenitore del montalatte Silvercrest ha una capacità di riscaldamento fino a 300 ml di latte, mentre per la montatura può ospitare fino a 150 ml. Queste quantità sono ideali per preparare porzioni abbondanti, perfette per una o due tazze senza sprechi. Il dispositivo si presta quindi non solo alla colazione, ma anche alla creazione di bevande calde o fredde durante tutta la giornata, ampliando le possibilità di utilizzo.
Lidl, consapevole del successo crescente dei suoi prodotti Silvercrest, avverte i clienti che la disponibilità potrebbe esaurirsi rapidamente. Il binomio tra qualità percepita e prezzo accessibile rende infatti questo montalatte una scelta conveniente e molto ricercata.
Con questa proposta, Lidl conferma il suo ruolo di protagonista nel mercato degli elettrodomestici da cucina economici ma di buon livello, offrendo a un pubblico sempre più vasto la possibilità di godersi un cappuccino come al bar, comodamente a casa propria.

L'articolo Bonus record fino
items.body:
Economia
                             
                        
                             
                                 Sostenibilità
                             
                                                
                                        Bonus record fino a 3.000€ all’anno: scopri subito se sei tra i lavoratori che lo possono ricevere

Roberto Arciola

Novembre 28, 2025

Il contributo Staff House: destinatari e condizioni (www.greenstyle.it)

Da fine novembre 2025, le imprese possono presentare domanda per accedere ad un nuovo incentivo economico.

Il contributo Staff House è rivolto a tutte le imprese del settore turistico che risultino attive con almeno uno dei codici ATECO indicati nell’articolo 3, comma 1, del decreto ministeriale del 18 settembre 2025. Questi codici identificano attività di servizi di alloggio e ristorazione, includendo realtà come hotel, ristoranti, bed and breakfast e altre strutture turistiche.
Ogni impresa può richiedere un contributo fino a 3.000 euro annui per ogni posto letto destinato ai propri dipendenti, finalizzato a coprire i costi di locazione degli alloggi. È però fondamentale che i canoni di affitto presentino una riduzione minima del 30% rispetto al valore medio di mercato, requisito essenziale per garantire la sostenibilità economica dell’iniziativa.
L’incentivo ha una durata variabile da 5 a 10 anni in base alla valutazione della domanda e alle specificità di ciascuna impresa, offrendo così una prospettiva di medio-lungo termine utile per la programmazione aziendale e la stabilizzazione delle condizioni abitative del personale.
Modalità di presentazione e tempistiche
Le imprese interessate devono presentare la domanda esclusivamente attraverso la piattaforma digitale di Invitalia. La finestra temporale per l’invio delle richieste si apre alle ore 12:00 del 21 novembre 2025 e si chiude alle 17:00 del 19 dicembre 2025. La selezione avverrà secondo l’ordine cronologico di arrivo delle domande, rendendo imprescindibile un’attenta preparazione e tempestività nella presentazione.
Questo sistema a sportello intende garantire trasparenza e equità nell’assegnazione delle risorse, ma impone alle aziende di muoversi rapidamente per non perdere l’opportunità.
Un supporto strategico per il turismo italiano – greenstyle.it
Il settore turistico, uno dei pilastri dell’economia italiana, sta affrontando sfide importanti legate alla gestione delle risorse umane e ai costi di esercizio, in particolare per quanto riguarda l’alloggio dei lavoratori stagionali e non. Il contributo Staff House risponde a questa esigenza, offrendo un sostegno concreto che permette alle imprese di ridurre l’incidenza dei costi abitativi e di migliorare le condizioni di vita dei dipendenti.
L’incentivo contribuisce a rafforzare la competitività delle aziende turistiche e a incrementare la qualità del lavoro nel settore, aspetti fondamentali per la ripresa e lo sviluppo sostenibile. Inoltre, la misura si inserisce nel più ampio quadro delle politiche di rilancio e valorizzazione del turismo italiano, promosse dal Ministero del Turismo e supportate dalla struttura operativa di Invitalia.
Invitalia: ruolo e missione nella gestione del contributo
Invitalia, l’Agenzia nazionale per lo sviluppo d’impresa sotto la vigilanza del Ministero dell’Economia e delle Finanze, rappresenta il cuore operativo di questa iniziativa. Con un report di sostenibilità 2024 che registra oltre 63.000 imprese finanziate e investimenti attivati per 17,4 miliardi di euro, Invitalia si conferma un attore chiave nel sostegno alla crescita economica del Paese.
L’agenzia, guidata dall’Amministratore Delegato Bernardo Mattarella e dal Presidente Sergio Schisani, ha il compito di gestire, monitorare e valutare l’erogazione del contributo Staff House, assicurando un processo efficiente e trasparente. La sua esperienza nella gestione di incentivi e fondi europei e nazionali garantisce un supporto tecnico di alto livello alle imprese beneficiarie.
Il contributo Staff House, con la sua durata fino a dieci anni, rappresenta una misura strategica che va oltre il mero sostegno temporaneo. Permette alle imprese di pianificare con maggiore sicurezza la gestione delle proprie risorse umane, favorendo un ambiente lavorativo più stabile e competitivo.
Questa iniziativa si inserisce in un contesto nazionale dove il turismo, dopo le fasi più critiche dell’emergenza sanitaria, punta a consolidare la propria ripresa attraverso strumenti innovativi e mirati, valorizzando il capitale umano come leva di crescita e qualità del servizio.

L'articolo Cellulite addio, sono questi gl
items.body:
Benessere
                             
                                                
                                        Cellulite addio, sono questi gli sport che la riducono davvero: abbiamo sempre sbagliato

Ilaria Macchi

Novembre 27, 2025

Praticare sport aiuta a eliminare la cellulite - Greenstyle.it

Eliminare la cellulite non è sempre così semplice, se non ci siamo ancora riusciti, però, forse non abbiamo praticato lo sport giusto. Ecco quali sono quelli più efficaci.

Curare la propria immagine piace a tutti, anche a chi fatica ad ammetterlo, ben sapendo come da questa possano dipendere molti dei giudizi che riceviamo, anche in ambito lavorativo. Non solo, se ci guardiamo allo specchio e amiamo quello che possiamo vedere ci sentiamo certamente meglio e siamo portati a dare il massimo in ogni ambito della nostra quotidianità. Nonostante gli sforzi di molti, però, può esserci un problema comune a molte donne, ma difficile da risolvere del tutto, ovvero la cellulite, che compare principalmente sulle gambe.
La pelle a buccia d’arancia, altro modo in cui possiamo definirla, può portare a tanti complessi, al punto tale da voler evitare a mettersi in costume o addirittura a sentirsi a disagio quando ci si deve mostrare al partner. In genere questa può essere frutto di un’alimentazione sbagliata e della scarsa ritenzione idrica, anche se non sempre si riesce a risolvere nemmeno modificando quello che mangiamo. Se si vuole risolvere davvero è il momento di mettere da parte la vita sedentaria e iniziare a praticare sport, ma è bene scegliere quelli che sono davvero efficaci.
Fai sport e puoi dire addio alla cellulite
Fare attività fisica è importante, lo sappiamo bene, con ogni probabilità ci è stato ripetuto decine di volte, sia per la nostra muscolatura, sia perché essere sedentari può portare a diversi disturbi. In realtà, questo può consentire anche di ottenere un beneficio importante a cui tanti aspirano, anche se forse non pensavano potesse garantire anche questo effetto, ovvero eliminare la cellulite.
Tutto questo può essere possibile, però, se sceegliamo con cognizione il tipo di sport più adatto, solo in questo modo potremo notare un calo effettivo della ritenzione idrica. I più pigri, convinti di non farcela, possono stare tranquilli, non servono grossi sforzi come quelli che sono chiamati a fare gli atleti per tenersi in forma, basta semplicemente programmare nell’arco della settimana una serie di sedute della durata di due ore e mezza, da diluire come si preferisce in base ai propri impegni. Sono sufficienti esercizi muscolari anche a bassa intensità, come una camminata veloce, ma anche andare in bicicletta o nuotare per 30-40 minuti almeno 2-3 volte la settimana.
Nuotare aiuta a ridurre la cellulite – Greenstyle.it
Gli appassionati di sport acquatici in modo particolare possono essere considerati tra i più fortunati, difficilmente accumuleranno la cellulite, innanzitutto perché i movimenti aiuteranno la circolazione (l’acqua è in grado di massaggiare), ma soprattutto si consumeranno calorie senza per questo fare grandi sacrifici a tavola.
Una volta conclusa l’attività, è comunque raccomandabile fare sempre stretching, oltre a fare esercizi tenendo le gambe in alto, così da sollecitare le vene e far fuoriuscire le tossine accumulate. Se si vogliono eliminare i liquidi presenti sulle gambe la corsa può essere un’ottima soluzione, ma chi non l’ha mai praticata prima dovrebbe aumentare il minutaggio solo in modo graduale.
A questo potremmo poi affiancare un massaggio drenante la mattina appena svegli e la sera prima di andare a dormire, oltre a un integratore disintossicante. Evitare gli accessi nell’alimentazione può essere però evidentemente altrettanto essenziale, meglio ridurre le quantità per i fritti e i cibi troppo zuccherati.

items.title: Alla memoria di Fulco Pratesi il Premio De Sanctis
items.description:
Riconoscimento voluto dalla Fondazione De Sanctis in collaborazione con il Ministero dell’Ambiente e della Sicurezza Energetica 
The post Alla memoria
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie C’è anche il fondatore del WWF Italia tra i premiati per la categoria sostenibilità E’ stato consegnato ieri nelle mani di Isabella Pratesi il Premio De Sanctis per la categoria “Sostenibilità” in ricordo di Fulco Pratesi. Scomparso lo scorso primo marzo, Fulco Pratesi ha tracciato la strada dell’ambientalismo in Italia, fondando nel 1966 il WWF Italia e guidandolo, da Presidente o Presidente onorario, per quasi 50 anni. Il Premio De Sanctis, giunto alla seconda edizione, è organizzato annualmente dalla fondazione omonima, in collaborazione con importanti istituzioni dello Stato, con l’obiettivo di valorizzare attraverso un riconoscimento di carattere internazionale le personalità che si sono distinte nei campi umanistici, sociali ed economici. Tra gli altri premiati anche il pittore Michelangelo Pistoletto, l’Udinese calcio per il Bluenergy stadium esempio virtuoso di infrastruttura sportiva all’avanguardia, un modello europeo di innovazione green, e il Generale Giuseppe Vadalà, Commissario unico per la bonifica delle discariche abusive. La consegna a Isabella Pratesi del Premio De Sanctis a Fulco Pratesi Il Premio è stato organizzato dalla Fondazione De Sanctis in collaborazione con il Ministero dell’Ambiente e della Sicurezza Energetica e con il patrocinio della Presidenza del Consiglio dei Ministri . Alla cerimonia era presente anche Luciano Di Tizio, Presidente del WWF Italia: “Come tutti i percorsi anche quello della sostenibilità ha avuto dei pionieri, personaggi visionari eppure illuminati che questo percorso lo hanno “visto” prima degli altri e hanno saputo indicarlo, nello scetticismo generale, accolti con diffidenza se non addirittura con sospetto. Tra questi ispirati pionieri in Italia c’è stato sicuramente Fulco Pratesi.Architetto, giornalista, naturalista, illustratore, è stato tra le figure più forti e carismatiche dell’ambientalismo italiano dell’ultimo secolo. Fulco Pratesi ha compreso prima di tanti altri come la tutela della natura costituisse il presupposto della vita umana soprattutto in un’epoca dove sempre più si attingono risorse senza lasciare ai sistemi naturali il tempo per rigenerarle”. Luciano Di Tizio “Quello che per noi oggi può apparire scontato, cioè che il percorso della sostenibilità necessiti di consapevolezza e che questa si conquisti anche con l’allargamento della partecipazione, per Fulco Pratesi è stato un vero obiettivo – ha detto ancora Di Tizio – . Per questo, negli anni 60, ha costituito, con un gruppo di autorevoli amici, il WWF Italia e ha lavorato per far sì che l’Associazione fosse diffusa, popolare, aperta al dialogo e al confronto, pur nella coerenza e nel rispetto dei propri valori, che erano e sono non soltanto di carattere scientifico, ma anche etici e morali.Le campagne lanciate da Fulco Pratesi con il WWF hanno consentito a questo Paese di essere migliore, hanno portato la fauna a essere considerata patrimonio indisponibile dello Stato, hanno salvato dall’estinzione certa specie cruciali per la biodiversità, come l’orso marsicano e il cervo sardo, la foca monaca e la lontra, hanno dotato l’Italia di leggi su caccia e parchi e dotato il nostro Paese di un sistema di aree protette di valore internazionale. Ma soprattutto è stato tra coloro che ci hanno aperto gli occhi su dove stiamo andando e su quello che mai dovremmo perdere o lasciare indietro ricordandoci che “la natura non ha bisogno dell’uomo ma l’uomo ha bisogno della natura”. 2 Marzo 2025 Fulco Pratesi: "La natura è un miracolo" L'ultima intervista del fondatore del WWF Italia e Presidente onorario, nonché direttore del Panda, rivista WWF

Article

Published: 27 November 2025

Wind forecast and prior community experience are associated with high preparedness for sequential tropical cyclones in the United States
                    Tianle Duan 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0009-0002-9297-105X1, Qingchun Li 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0769-02381, Fengxiu Zhang2, Dazhi Xi 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-4096-84413 & …Ning Lin 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5571-16064 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 977 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate changeInterdisciplinary studiesNatural hazards

AbstractSequential tropical cyclone events, in which two tropical cyclones make landfall in the same region within a short time, are becoming increasingly likely. Here we investigate community preparedness for six sequential tropical cyclone events in the United States from 2020 to 2024. We adopt spatial regression models and use human mobility trends as a proxy for preparedness, integrating weather forecast information, hazards experience, infrastructure conditions, and socioeconomic factors. During sequential tropical cyclone events, communities show higher preparedness levels in response to stronger forecast winds, while this tendency declines during the second tropical cyclone compared with the first one. Power outage experience from the first tropical cyclone is associated with higher preparedness levels for the subsequent one. Communities with access and functional needs consistently show lower preparedness levels for sequential tropical cyclones. The results offer timely insights to inform community preparedness strategies under growing risks of sequential tropical cyclones.

                        IntroductionUnder climate change, destructive hurricanes and tropical storms are becoming increasingly likely to strike coastal areas in quick succession1. Sequential tropical cyclones (TCs) — defined here as two TCs making landfall in the same region within a short time period — can cause compounded damage to affected areas2. Unlike successive TCs occurring over several years, sequential TCs are marked by their temporally compressed impacts. When severe storms strike communities in rapid succession, the resulting loss and damage can be substantially amplified due to cascading effects and limited time for recovery between events1,2. For instance, a rapid sequences of three hurricanes (Dennis, Floyd, and Irene) that struck North Carolina between September and October 1999 triggered massive freshwater flushing and ecological disruption to Pamlico Sound, the lagoonal estuary in the United States3. A recent example is Hurricanes Helene (2024) and Milton (2024) which made landfall in Florida within two weeks. Hurricane Helene struck Florida on September 26 as a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph, the strongest hurricane on record to impact the Big Bend region. It caused 225 fatalities, making it the deadliest Atlantic hurricane since Hurricane Maria in 20174. Less than two weeks later, on October 9, Hurricane Milton hit Florida as a Category 3 hurricane, inflicting repeated damage to homes, businesses, vehicles, and other infrastructure in coastal areas and claiming 24 lives4. The latest updated estimates indicate that the economic losses from this sequential TC event could reach up to $100 billion5,6.Preparedness for adverse events is critical for enhancing community resilience and enabling effective adaptation to emerging climate-related risks7,8. The National Academies define community resilience as the capacity of human and infrastructure systems to anticipate, absorb, recover from, or more successfully adapt to actual or potential adverse events, emphasizing the integral role of human systems in building resilience9. Communities act as the brain of the city, directing its activities, responding to its needs, and learning from its experience8, thereby highlighting their adaptive and transformative capabilities in promoting resilience to adverse events10,11. Unlike successive hurricanes that strike the same location over multiple years, sequential TC hazards impose a much shorter recovery interval between storms, presenting distinct and urgent challenges for community preparedness and resilience. When severe storms occur in quick succession, they can rapidly deplete resources, erode individuals’ mental well-being and complicate risk perception, ultimately diminishing their capacity and willingness to prepare for, respond to, and recover from consecutive hazards12,13,14. Worse still, the probability of sequential TC hazards occurring is projected to increase steadily1. Under a high-emissions scenario, the annual occurrence probability of two sequential category 4 or 5 hurricanes striking the same region could exceed 1% by the end of the century2. This emergence of sequential TC hazards highlights the importance of studying and investigating people’s situational preparedness dynamics for such hazards.At the individual or household level, TC preparedness includes short-term (e.g., evacuation, storing food and drinks, and reinforcing structural safety) and long-term measures (e.g., purchasing insurance, stockpiling essentials, and setting mitigation funds)15,16,17,18,19. A community’s preparedness for a TC event is not only driven by the meteorological hazards, but also by a range of intersecting factors, including its socioeconomic status, access and functional needs (AFNs), forecast weather information, prior experience with TC-induced meteorological impacts, infrastructure disruptions, and spillover effects. Existing research has widely identified the association between socioeconomic status and TC preparedness, findings consistently showing that those with lower income, minority racial or ethnic backgrounds, and lower educational attainment are often less likely to engage in proactive TC preparedness20,21. Particularly, individuals with AFNs, including but not limited to those with disabilities, limited language proficiency, restricted mobility, and economic disadvantages as well as children and seniors, face additional challenges in preparing for emergency events22,23. However, those individuals have received limited attention in research and practice24,25. Extant studies also recognize that risk perception of future TC hazards and prior TC experience would increase the likelihood of adopting preparedness measures26,27,28. Weather forecasts serve as the primary channel through which people access weather information, assess hazard risks, and take appropriate preparedness actions29. People take more active preparedness when they perceive higher upcoming risks (e.g., stronger forecast winds and heavier forecast rainfall). Prior TC experience also influences preparedness, as individuals who have previously faced such hazards may develop greater risk perception as well as confidence in their ability to respond effectively30,31. Particularly, severe TC experience (e.g., experienced strong winds and heavy rainfall) activates preparedness as people become more aware of the risks and the urgency for early actions. On the other hand, it is also possible that the affected community would develop complacency under repeated hurricane threats and fail to undertake preparedness measures13. A community’s preparedness is further influenced by spillover effects from its neighboring communities, driven by interdependent infrastructure systems, shared culture, and policy coordination32,33,34,35. Infrastructure disruptions in a region—such as power outages and road congestion—can induce broader impacts on neighboring areas by limiting access to essential services and evacuation routes36. Hence, even low-intensity TCs can cause substantial property damage and loss of life when preparedness is lacking (see Supplementary Note 1 for an example of Hurricane Ida (2021) casualties in different states). To summarize, community preparedness for storms is shaped by meteorological hazards and a range of demographic, socioeconomic, infrastructural, and informational factors, the dynamics of which are likely to become more complex during sequential TCs. Although previous studies have examined various drivers of community preparedness, none have investigated the mechanisms of preparedness during sequential TC events, a gap our study aims to fill.Regarding methodology, the existing literature has predominantly analyzed preparedness decisions using surveys either in the absence of disasters or long after disasters had occurred37. These surveys are typically cross-sectional and tend to focus on a specific region or a single event, thus failing to capture local adaptation strategies and policies over time or across different regions38. A complementary strand of research utilizes big mobility data to explore the dynamics of preparedness for individual hurricanes. Big mobility data are larger-scale, anonymized location data collected from mobile devices, which capture human movement patterns at high spatial and temporal resolutions39,40. For instance, Dargin et al. utilized GPS trajectory data to analyze preparedness behaviors for Hurricane Harvey, revealing a statistically significant increase in visits to specific points of interest (POIs) before Harvey, such as gasoline stations, grocery stores, and insurance carriers41. Deng et al. used high-resolution human mobility data to explore disparate evacuation patterns among social groups before, during, and after Hurricane Harvey15. Li et al. used mobile phone location data to examine income and racial disparities in preparedness for Hurricane Ida (2021) across multiple affected states16. Duan et al. leveraged smartphone data to uncover how the affected communities utilized cooling centers to adapt to extreme heat in the aftermath of hurricane-induced power outage42. Nevertheless, no existing studies have investigated preparedness dynamics in sequential TC scenarios. In the meantime, some prior research has provided initial evidence of temporal dependence in preparedness behaviors between sequential TCs, serving as a motivation for this study. For example, a study leveraging large-scale mobility data compared preparedness behaviors during Hurricane Ida (2021) in the affected states16. The findings revealed a lower preparedness level for Hurricane Ida in New York than in Louisiana; however, New York exhibited an earlier and stronger preparedness responses for Hurricane Henri (2021), which likely influenced subsequent preparedness for Hurricane Ida. To deepen our understanding of the temporal dependence of community disaster preparedness, we investigate individual- or household-level situational preparedness dynamics for sequential TC hazards using big mobility data.In this study, we focus on TCs that made landfall with at least tropical storm intensity (i.e., wind speed greater than 34 knots). We focus on cases where two TCs affected the same state within 21 days, the typical recovery period for a single TC event (See Supplementary Note 2 for the selection of a 21-day interval)43. We study the identified six pairs of sequential TCs that affected seven U.S. states (i.e., Louisiana, Texas, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Florida) between 2020 and 2024. Using big mobility data, we investigate three situational TC preparedness types (i.e., preparedness for mobility needs, daily supplies, and structural reinforcement) by identifying statistically significant increases in visits to POIs (e.g., gasoline stations, grocery stores, and building material dealers). We account for a comprehensive set of factors influencing preparedness behaviors, including forecast TC wind intensity, experienced TC wind intensity and infrastructure disruptions, access and functional needs, and socioeconomic variables. We designed a group of regression analyses to investigate (1) the combined effects of sequential TCs’ intensity and landfall sequence on people’s preparedness behaviors, (2) the role of communities’ AFNs in preparedness disparities, and (3) the impacts of first TCs on the preparedness for the second TCs. This study advances the understanding of the human dimensions of TC impacts, providing insights into disaster management policies for back-to-back natural hazards.ResultsSix pairs of sequential TCs landfalling in the US from 2020 to 2024We identified six pairs of sequential TC events between 2020 and 2024 in the United States, that affected seven states. Figure 1 illustrates the forecast track and the forecast uncertainty of the identified sequential TCs.Fig. 1: Six sequential tropical cyclone events in the Contiguous United States from 2020 to 2024.Red areas are cones of uncertainty and dashed lines are the forecast paths of tropical cyclones. Data source: National Hurricane Center operational forecast data archive74. Each cone of uncertainty is based on the forecast track issued 48 ± 6 h before its landfall in the state that experienced sequential tropical cyclone events (highlighted in gray in each subplot).Full size imageDisparate POI visit trends during sequential TC preparednessWe analyzed people’s visits to POIs during the six sequential TC events. We identified three situational preparedness types, characterized by statistically significant increases in POI visits before TC landfall: visiting gasoline stations to prepare for mobility needs, visiting grocery stores to stock up on daily supplies, and visiting building material and supplies dealers to reinforce structural safety, consistent with the findings of our previous works16,41 and existing literature44,45,46. Figure 2 illustrates the three types of POI visit trends during Helene and Milton and statistically significant preparedness pattern at the Brevard County, Florida.Fig. 2: Brevard County during Helene-Milton (2024) sequential tropical cyclone event.a Hurricane tracks and wind speeds in counties in Florida; b Visits to Points of Interest during Helene-Milton.Full size imagePreparedness for TCs can be driven by forecast weather information and the population’s concerns about potential extreme conditions. Also, counties within the same state may experience different intensities of TC due to variations in their distance from the TC path, providing a diverse set of observations. Figure 2a illustrates the hurricane paths of Hurricane Helene (2024) and Hurricane Milton (2024), which made sequential landfalls in Florida, affecting preparedness in Brevard County. As shown in Fig. 2, Brevard County experienced lower wind speed during Helene than Milton (13.8 ms–1 versus 35.4 ms−1) because it is far from Helene’s track. However, it showed higher preparedness levels for mobility needs and daily supplies observed for Helene than for Milton, while it showed a lower preparedness level for structural reinforcement for Helene. This finding implies combined effects of forecast intensity and landfall sequence on the preparedness for sequential TCs.We conducted analysis at the county level (i.e., all variables collected or mapped to a county-level resolution) to capture the aggregated individual- or household-level preparedness behaviors. We defined a county-level aggregated preparedness pattern as a statistically significant increase in POI visits before TCs, where visits exceeded two standard deviations above the baseline (see Methods for details). Analyzing the six sequential TCs listed above and the 680 affected county cases, we found disparate situational preparedness patterns across events and illustrated the patterns in Fig. 3. For mobility needs preparedness, 165 out of the 680 observations show county-level aggregated preparedness patterns for both TCs, 57 observations show patterns for the first TC only, 101 show patterns for the second TC only, and the remaining 357 show no statistically significant preparedness pattern. For daily supplies (structural reinforcement) preparedness, 163 (106) counties have situational preparedness patterns for both TCs, 44 (71) for the first TC only, 146 (92) for the second TC only, and 327 (441) have no preparedness patterns. The level of preparedness efforts, measured by the percentage of increase in POI visits compared to baseline (see Methods for details), also varies across preparedness types. For mobility needs preparedness, 241 of the 680 observations show higher preparedness levels for the first TC than for the second TC, and the other 439 observations show higher preparedness levels for the second TC. For daily supplies preparedness and structural reinforcement preparedness, the comparison is 272 versus 408, and 246 versus 434, respectively. The disparate patterns imply combined effects of TC intensity and landfall sequence (i.e., the first or second landfalling TC in a sequential TC event) on people’s situational preparedness, as investigated below.Fig. 3: Disparate preparedness patterns and preparedness levels for sequential tropical cyclones across counties.We define preparedness level as the percentage of increase in visits to Points of Interest compared with the baseline and preparedness pattern as the increase in visits exceeding two standard deviations above the baseline. Numbers and percentages of counties experience sequential tropical cyclone effects are shown in the figure.Full size imageCombined effects of forecast wind and landfall sequence on mobility needs preparednessWe performed spatial regression models (N = 1360) to investigate the disparities in the levels of preparedness for the first and second landfall TCs. Each data sample represents a county affected by an individual TC, distinguishing its landfall sequence with a dummy variable, where a subsequent TC is labeled as 1 and the first TC as 0. Linear models capture the continuous changes in the level of preparedness efforts and quantify the variances. We used the level of preparedness efforts, measured by the percentage of a county’s increase in POI visits compared to the baseline (see methods for details), as the dependent variable. Table 1 presents the regression results on mobility needs preparedness using Multiple Linear Regression (MLR, the baseline model) and Spatial Durbin Model (SDM). We presented the results of other supplementary models (Spatial Error Model and Spatial Lag Model) in Supplementary Table S1. SDM includes controls for the spatial lag of both the dependent and selected independent variables to return an unbiased estimate of the impact of the covariates of interest. Among the models we tested, SDM has the highest log-likelihood value (1342.42), justifying it as the most suitable model to explain the factors influencing preparedness for sequential TCs. In the following sections, we will mainly explain our findings based on SDM (i.e., Model 2).Table 1 Linear spatial regression models on mobility needs preparedness levelsFull size tableIn the SDM model, forecast wind speed, landfall sequence, and their interaction term are statistically significantly correlated with the mobility needs preparedness level. Specifically, every unit increase (i.e., 1 m s−1) in the forecasted wind speed corresponds to an average increase of 0.34% (95% Confidence Interval (CI): [0.16%, 0.52%]) in mobility needs preparedness. After controlling for other factors, second landfall TCs receive an average of 2.02% (95% CI: [0.45%, 3.59%]) more preparedness than the first landfall. However, the coefficient of the interaction term indicates that for each unit increase in forecast wind speed, the level of mobility needs preparedness for the first TC is 0.12% (95% CI: [0.01%, 0.23%]) higher than the preparedness for the second one. The marginal effect of forecast wind speed on preparedness level diminishes for the second hurricane relative to the first TC.The combined effects of landfall sequence and forecast wind speed reveal that populations are more alert to the second landfall TCs but appear less sensitive to forecast wind speed. From a psychological perspective, experiencing back-to-back hurricanes may lead to psychological fatigue, reducing responsiveness to risk signals such as forecast wind speed47,48,49,50. From a resource perspective, preparedness for the first TCs would consume essential but limited resources (e.g., money and supplies), leaving fewer means for subsequent preparedness for the second TCs18. These dynamics highlight that back-to-back hazards would result in compound risks for communities, and we will further elaborate on it in the Discussion section.Spatial dependence and state fixed effects in mobility needs preparednessThe spatial term in SDM (\(\rho =\) 0.4321, 95% CI: [0.3685, 0.4958]) indicates the presence of spatial dependence. The spatial terms in the spatial error model and spatial lag model consistently demonstrate the spatial dependence of preparedness between counties. Throughout the linear spatial regression models, we controlled for state-level fixed effects by including dummy variables for each state. We used Florida as the baseline category, so it does not appear as a variable in the SDM model. The statistically significant negative coefficients (see Supplementary Table S1) of Texas, New York, New Jersey, and North Carolina indicate that counties in these states have an average of lower preparedness efforts compared to Florida, holding other factors constant. Louisiana and South Carolina show no statistically significant difference in their preparedness efforts compared with Florida. This implies that Louisiana, Florida, and South Carolina share a comparable culture of preparedness among residents, likely due to their long history of frequent and severe hurricane exposure, along with policy initiatives and public awareness campaigns focused on hurricane preparedness.Access and functional needs potentially restrict mobility needs preparednessAFN factors in Model 2 exhibit statistically significant associations with the mobility needs preparedness level. The percentage of people under 5 (coefficient −0.0245, 95% CI: [−0.0287, −0.0203]), the percentage of people over 65 (coefficient −0.0040, 95% CI: [−0.0053, −0.0028]), limited language proficiency (coefficient −0.3465, 95% CI: [−0.5239, −0.1690]) are negatively correlated with preparedness level. It suggests that AFNs potentially constrain populations’ capability to visit gasoline stations for mobility needs. The proportion of people with disabilities and the lack of vehicle availability show no statistically significant evidence. We used POI density to estimate the resource availability for preparedness actions, which is also not statistically significant (coefficient-0.0017, 95% CI: [−0.0300, 0.0267]). This lack of significance may indicate that simply having a higher density of resources, such as stores and service centers, does not necessarily translate to increased preparedness51. Factors such as accessibility, physical mobility, transportation options, and public risk awareness play a more critical role in shaping preparedness behavior.Effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence on other preparedness typesThe statistical evidence of the combined effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence is weaker on preparedness for daily supplies and structural reinforcement. We illustrated the effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence in Fig. 4 and presented the full regression analysis in Supplementary Table S2. The combined effects are not statistically significant for these two preparedness types at the 95% confidence interval. One possible explanation is that the count of visits to grocery stores and building material dealers does not capture the extent of preparedness as effectively as visits to gasoline stations. Factors such as the average one-time payment amount, daily sales, and the types of goods purchased are also meaningful indicators of situational preparedness, but these aspects cannot be reflected solely by visit counts52,53.Fig. 4: Combined effects of forecast wind speed and landfall sequence on daily supplies and structural reinforcement preparedness.Numbers in the figure represent coefficients of variables, controlling for other variables. The 95% CI represents the confidence interval at a 95% confidence level.Full size imageDiscussionSequential TC hazards are becoming increasingly likely in the United States. The temporal compression of their impacts can strain community preparedness by quickly depleting resources, complicating risk perception, and limiting the time available to restock supplies, make repairs, and recover between events. To study situational preparedness dynamics during sequential TC hazards, we investigated three situational preparedness types, namely mobility needs preparedness, daily supplies preparedness, and structural reinforcement preparedness. We identified six sequential TC events from 2020 to 2024, which affected Louisiana, Texas, New Jersey, New York, North and South Carolina, and Florida, all landfalling with at least tropical storm intensity (i.e., wind speed greater than 34 knots). We found that forecast TC intensity and landfall sequence have combined effects on preparedness. Stronger forecast wind is statistically significantly associated with a higher level of preparedness, indicating people can perceive higher risks from the forecast intensity. Controlling for TC intensity, people tend to have higher levels of preparedness for the second landfalling TC in a sequential TC event. Meanwhile, people are more sensitive to the forecast wind speed for the first TC than to that for the subsequent one. Investigating the first TC’s impacts on preparedness for the second TCs, we found that experiencing a severe power outage from a previous TC would increase mobility needs preparedness and structural reinforcement preparedness for the subsequent TC. We did not see this pattern for daily supplies preparedness. We identified spatial dependency in mobility needs preparedness for TCs across counties. Power outage experiences in the first TC show spillover effects on mobility needs and daily supplies preparedness for the second TC.A higher level of preparedness for the second landfalling TC suggests that the first TC heightened people’s risk perception. Our findings support existing research showing that increasing risk perception can promote protective behavior in response to natural hazards, as reflected in a greater willingness to prepare and a stronger public response20,54,55,56. The consumption of household resources during the first TC may also drive higher preparedness levels for the second hurricane, as people need to replenish essential supplies. Another key finding is that the increasing forecast wind speed has a stronger effect on the increasing preparedness efforts for the first TC than for the second TC. It aligns with existing research on the anchoring effects that influence decision-making for future hazards, as people may rely on their experiences during the first TC to assess the risk of the upcoming TC57,58. Lower sensitivity to the second TC forecast wind speed can also be attributed to mental fatigue50, since natural hazards can induce psychological stress and mental health challenge47,48,49,59,60. People might also develop complacency or a false sense of security after surviving the first TC. Empirical evidence shows that the government plays a critical role in managing public complacency, especially as an information provider and preparation facilitator13. Therefore, it is crucial for local governments to communicate the ongoing risks of sequential storms and emphasize the importance of maintaining sustained preparedness and provide clear guidance on how to effectively prepare. Those efforts are particularly vital in coastal regions where the risk of sequential TCs is elevated. From another perspective, preparedness efforts for the first TC can deplete essential resources, leaving fewer means for subsequent preparedness. Hence, it is also crucial for the government to strengthen infrastructure and logistics systems to pre-position resources in advance or allocate them before and during sequential TC events. This approach ensures that communities are well-equipped to respond, thereby minimizing the compound impacts of back-to-back hazards.Our results suggest that power outage experiences in the first TCs would increase people’s preparedness for the subsequent TCs. It aligns with existing research findings that people worrying about power outages tend to have a higher preparedness for potential outages in the future61. Power outage risks are not solely driven by wind speed but are also closely linked to factors such as grid resilience, wind gusts, vegetation management, and land use62,63,64,65,66,67. We did not control for these factors influencing power outages as they fall outside the scope of this study’s focus on preparedness. Power outage experiences during the first TC exhibit spatial spillover effects on neighboring counties’ preparedness for the second event, indicating that prior disruptions influence regional responses beyond county boundaries. We also found statistically significant spatial lag in neighboring counties’ preparedness levels, suggesting interconnection across neighboring counties’ preparedness. These results suggest that county-level preparedness for an approaching TC interacts with neighboring counties due to interdependent infrastructure, sharing ideology, and policy coordination32,33,34. Additionally, state fixed effects reveal variation in preparedness efforts across states, suggesting that differing government ideologies on TC hazards may influence state level TC preparedness68.Our analysis reveals statistically significant disparities in preparedness patterns among individuals with Access and Functional Needs (AFNs). Notably, preparedness for mobility needs is most severely impacted when TC occurs, as communities with higher proportions of children under 5, elderly individuals over 65, people with disabilities, households with language barriers, and those without vehicles tend to demonstrate lower preparedness levels. These findings underscore the importance of designing targeted, inclusive preparedness strategies that address the specific challenges faced by these groups, particularly in relation to limited mobility during disaster events. It is essential to invest in emergency infrastructure that supports accessible transportation options, such as ramps, accessible vehicles, and safe evacuation routes. Additionally, inclusive transportation planning is critical, ensuring that public transit and emergency evacuation systems are designed to accommodate the diverse mobility needs of these populations.The increasing frequency of sequential TC events presents additional challenge to community resilience. Previous research on compound hazards mainly focused on simultaneous events, such as compound flooding, heatwaves, and storm-induced power outages69,70,71. Sequential TC hazards strike the same community in quick succession1,2. While a community could be resilient enough to absorb and recover from a single hurricane, the second hurricane might arrive during a vulnerable recovery period, overwhelming the community’s resilience capacity. Our study uncovered the disparities between preparedness efforts for the first and second TCs, the first TCs’ impacts on preparedness for the second TCs, spatial dependence in preparedness across counties, spillover effects of infrastructure disruptions (e.g., power outages), and the role of AFN factors in TC preparedness. Our findings advance the understanding of people’s preparedness for sequential TC hazards, while providing insights for improving risk reduction strategies to address the sequentially compound hazards and highlighting the need for targeted outreach and support to assist people with AFNs. Under the high emission scenario (i.e. SSP5–8.5), the likelihood of sequential tropical cyclone hazards impacting the same location within 21 days is projected to increase substantially by the end of the 21st century, with annual probabilities exceeding 50% across many locations along the US East and Gulf coasts1,2. By examining recent cases of sequential TCs, this study provides timely insights to inform community preparedness strategies and guide policymaking in the face of escalating future challenges.This study has limitations. According to the resilience lifecycle model, an extremely short interval implies that the second TC strikes while the community is still experiencing disruptions and has not yet begun the recovery process72. In such cases, situational preparedness may be low due to limited capacity instead of a lack of willingness. Conversely, a relatively longer interval facilitates preparedness efforts. We tried to incorporate the interval between each pair of sequential TCs in our analysis. Given the availability of mobility data and power outage data, the limited cases provided limited distinct values of intervals for observations, failing to facilitate a robust analysis. We did not find a statistically significant correlation between the interval between two sequential TCs and the level of situational preparedness. Moreover, due to limitations in data availability, we did not model flood severity. Although we included experienced rainfall as a proxy for flood potential, future work should explore additional datasets and develop more robust methods to control for the effects of flooding on preparedness dynamics. We did not model road network conditions or transportation disruptions due to data availability. Integrating road conditions and transportation disruptions in future research could help capture access constraints during extreme weather. In addition, our analysis does not differentiate between people’s willingness and capability to prepare. In high-intensity or prolonged TC events, people may be unable or feel unsafe leaving their homes to visit gasoline stations, grocery stores, or building supply shops. Future work can explore additional datasets and develop new methods to distinguish the impacts of capacity constraints from willingness on preparedness. Finally, future research could benefit from incorporating transaction-level data to differentiate between consumable and reusable preparedness resources, providing a more nuanced understanding of short- versus long-term risk mitigation strategies.MethodData pre-processingThe following sections introduce the data we used. We pre-processed all the data to county resolution according to the TCs’ affected regions and periods.Mobility dataWe used the mobility data provided by Dewey Inc. to assess situational preparedness during sequential TC hazards73. The mobility data reports daily visits to POIs and their geographic locations. To account for a consistent weekly pattern of POI visits (i.e., higher visits on weekends than weekdays), we calculated the 7-day rolling average of daily POI visits, representing the preparedness efforts in a continuous 7-day period. We defined the preparedness period for a TC as the 7-day period before its landfall. Setting a baseline for each county, we used the average of the 7-day rolling average from four weeks to one week before the sequential TC events (i.e., 21 days before the preparedness period). To estimate the preparedness efforts for each TC event, we calculated the ratio of the maximum 7-day rolling average during the preparedness period (representing peak visits to POIs in a continuous 7-day period) to the baseline value. A ratio value exceeding two standard deviations above the baseline represents a statistically significant increase in POI visits. We defined this threshold exceedance as the presence of a county-level preparedness pattern for the upcoming TC. We defined preparedness level as the percentage of increasing visits to POIs compared to the baseline, which is the ratio value minus 1. The presence (or absence) of a preparedness pattern is the dependent variable in logistic regression models. Preparedness level serves as the dependent variable in linear regression models.Using the POI locations provided by the mobility data, we calculated POI density for each county by dividing the total number of specific POIs (e.g., gasoline stations) in a county by the county’s land area.Historical windWe utilized the Best Track Data (HURDAT2) from the National Hurricane Center (NHC) to extract the paths and associated wind radii of TCs74. HURDAT2 provides data at a 6-h resolution, which we interpolated to a 1-h resolution. We used a TC wind field model to produce the TC radial profile of the near-surface rotating wind75,76,77. We recorded the estimated maximum sustained wind speed for each county as the wind impacts from the first TCs.Historical rainfallWe used the NCEP/EMC 4KM Gridded (GRIB) Stage IV Data to estimate historical rainfall during a TC event78. We averaged the values of gridded data points within a county’s boundary to estimate the rainfall of the county. To assess the rainfall impacts from the first TCs, we calculated the maximum rainfall volume over any continuous 24-h period79.Forecast windThe forecast information was sourced from the NHC Tropical Cyclone Archive, which contains all hurricane forecasts produced since the center’s establishment in 195474,80. These forecasts include track and intensity predictions generated every 6 h throughout the life cycle of a TC. We used the forecast maximum wind speed to estimate the forecast intensity of the TCs.Power outageThe Environment for Analysis of Geo-Located Energy Information (EAGLE-ITM) data, maintained by Oak Ridge National Laboratory, reports the number of customers experiencing electricity outages every 15 min at the county level81,82. To estimate the total number of customers in a county \({c}_{i}\), we used the following formula provided by the data publisher82:$${c}_{i}={p}_{i}* \frac{C}{P}$$
                    (1)
                where \(C\) is the total number of customers in the state, \(P\) is the population of the state, and \({p}_{i}\) is the population of county within the state. When \({c}_{i,{out}}\) represent the customers without power in county \(i\), the extent of power outages, estimated by the power outage rate in a county, follows.$${Power\; outage\; rate}=\frac{{c}_{i,{out}}}{{c}_{i}}$$
                    (2)
                Factors of sociodemographic and access and functional needsTo control for the effects of sociodemographic factors on TC preparedness and explore the effects of access and functional needs, we involved the county level household median income, percentage of white population, percentage of people under 5 years old, the percentage of people over 65 years old, the percentage of disabled people aged 5–65, the percentage of households with limited English proficiency, and the percentage of households without vehicles in our study. We collected the data mentioned above from US Census Bureau83.Statistical analysisWe performed spatial regression models to explore: (1) the disparities in preparedness between the first and second TCs; (2) the role of AFNs in preparedness for TCs; and (3) the first TCs’ influences on the preparedness for the subsequent TCs. The Spatial Durbin Model (SDM) assumes the spatial dependence exists in both the dependent variable and the independent variables, which follows the baseline specification:$${y}_{j}=\rho W{y}_{j}+{X}_{j}\beta +W{Z}_{j}\theta +{D\alpha }_{s}+{\varepsilon }_{j}$$
                    (3)
                where \({y}_{j}\) is the vector of county preparedness levels before TC \(j\). \(W\) is the spatial weight matrix defined using the Queen contiguity criterion. \(W{y}_{j}\) thus represent the spatially weighted average of preparedness among the neighboring counties of each county before TC \(j\). \({X}_{j}\) is the matrix of independent variables, including climatology, infrastructure, socioeconomic and AFN factors introduced above. \(\beta\) represents the coefficients associated with \({X}_{j}\). \({Z}_{j}\) is a subset of \({X}_{j}\), including factors affecting infrastructure connection between counties. \(\rho\) and \(\theta\) characterize the strength of the spatial dependence for the dependent and independent variables, respectively. \({D\alpha }_{s}\) represents state-level fixed effects. \({\varepsilon }_{j}\) is the residual error term. Alternative models include multiple linear regression (MLR), spatial error models (SEM), and spatial lag models (SLR). Each of these alternative approaches serves as a restricted version of the SDM, imposing certain parameter constraints.We employed spatial logistic models on the presence (or absence) of county-level aggregated preparedness patterns in sequential TC events to demonstrate the robustness of linear models. The spatial logistic model follows a specification:$${logit}\left(P\left({y}_{j}=1\right)\right)=\rho W{y}_{j}+{X}_{j}\beta +W{Z}_{j}\theta +{D\alpha }_{s}$$
                    (4)
                where \({y}_{j}\) is the vector of binary variables (\(y=1\) for the presence of a county-level preparedness pattern and \(y=0\) for its absence). Other terms remain the same with linear models.

Bedrock uplift reduces Antarctic sea-level contribution over next centuries
                    C. J. van Calcar 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-4659-06781,2, J. Bernales1,3, C. J. Berends 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-2961-03501, W. van der Wal
